titleStmt.title: The roman*cisa*on of mental health problems in adolescents and its implica*ons: A narra*ve review

analytic.title: The roman*cisa*on of mental health problems in adolescents and its implica*ons: A narra*ve review

startPage=-1, endPage=-1, consolidateCitations=0, consolidateHeader=1, consolidateFunders=0, includeRawAffiliations=false, includeRawCitations=false, includeRawCopyrights=false, generateTeiIds=false, generateTeiCoordinates=[], sentenceSegmentation=false, flavor=null

div.p: RomanLcisaLon is the percepLon and portrayal of a phenomenon as more aMracLve, interesLng, cool, profound, or desirable than it really is. There are concerns that mental health problems are increasingly romanLcised, parLcularly among adolescents, but there is limited research on this topic. This narraLve review invesLgated: (1) what romanLcisaLon is in the context of adolescent mental health problems, (2) why adolescents might romanLcise mental health problems, (3) the implicaLons of romanLcising mental health problems in adolescence, and ( 4) what intervenLons might reduce this phenomenon. Sixty-one publicaLons were reviewed, including qualitaLve and quanLtaLve analyses, cross-secLonal and longitudinal self-report studies and conceptual reviews. Most invesLgated romanLcisaLon of mental health problems online. IdenLty formaLon, popular media influences and peer influences arose as potenLal explanatory factors. NegaLve outcomes to romanLcisaLon were indicated, including the reinforcement of mental health problems and reduced help-seeking; few intervenLons to reduce the phenomenon have been proposed to date.

RomanLcisaLon is the unrealisLc belief, percepLon, or representaLon of something to be more desirable or aMracLve than it really is (Issaka et al., 2024). Objects of romanLcisaLon are presented as idyllic, aestheLc, trendy, or interesLng, while negaLve aspects are minimised or dismissed. In recent years, there has been growing concern that mental health problemsdefined here as mental disorders and their subclinical symptoms -have been increasingly romanLcised in Western countries, parLcularly among adolescents (Dunn, 2017a;Rick, 2016;Schipper, 2022). Examples can easily be found on social media plaborms such as Instagram, Facebook, TwiMer, TikTok and Tumblr, which show aestheLcally-pleasing photos and videos of people crying, bleak landscapes, or images of severe weight loss and self-harm, accompanied by song or movie quotes, or poeLc capLons that express suffering and mental distress (Bine, 2013;Rick, 2016). The concern is that this romanLcisaLon can spread misinformaLon and trivialise the difficulLes experienced by people with mental health problems, ulLmately increasing distress for these individuals (Gupta et al., 2021;Shrestha, 2018).

In the past two decades, there have been extensive efforts led by chariLes, public health bodies and popular media to reduce the sLgma associated with mental health problems (Tam et al., 2024), and these efforts may have inadvertently contributed to romanLcisaLon of these difficulLes. Many people now share their personal experiences of mental health problems online, including celebriLes, medical professionals and lay people (Emmers-Sommer & Terán, 2020;Gronholm & Thornicroi, 2022;Pretorius et al., 2022). These personal accounts of mental health problems are oien rewarded with praise and aMenLon in the form of 'likes', comments and followers, which are powerful indicators of social acceptance (Lindström et al., 2021;Sherman et al., 2016). This form of reward might then lead social media users to draw an associaLon between their own mental health problems and posiLve social outcomes (Dunn, 2017a).

Most concerns about romanLcisaLon of mental health problems focus on adolescents (Bine, 2013;Rick, 2016), and there are a number of factors relaLng to social cogniLve development during this period that indicate they may be especially likely to romanLcise mental health problems. Adolescents use the internet, and parLcularly social media, to seek emoLonal support and learn about mental health (Pretorius et al., 2020;Tifferet, 2020); this increases the likelihood of exposure to romanLcised content that may influence their amtudes and behaviour. Adolescents are more suscepLble to social influence than adults, including conforming to the amtudes and behaviours shown by their peers (Foulkes et al., 2018;Knoll et al., 2015). They may also be more sensiLve to social reward, meaning that the social currency of likes, comments and follows are especially moLvaLng for them (Foulkes & Blakemore, 2016). This may lead them to romanLcise mental health problems online to seem 'cool' and gain aMenLon and support from peers (Dunn, 2017a;Rick, 2016). Lastly, adolescence is a criLcal period of idenLty formaLon, where a sense of belonging with peers is crucial for developing a posiLve sense of self (Ragelienė, 2016). Adolescents also use social media to support their idenLty development (Granic et al., 2020). Mimicking the romanLcisaLon that they see online might help adolescents belong to a social group, which in turn contributes to their developing sense of self. However, these are inferences based on theory and evidence of adolescents' social cogniLve development; to date, there have been limited aMempts to review research that more directly examines romanLcisaLon of mental health problems at this age.

In parLcular, it is criLcal to understand not just why adolescents might romanLcise mental health problems but what impact it might have on them. RomanLcisaLon may have some benefits -some individuals may feel validated or understood by hearing others talk about mental health problems in this way, and may romanLcise themselves to make sense or cope with the issue (Brotsky & Giles, 2007a;Hendry, 2020). However, in parallel, there are concerns that romanLcisaLon may have negaLve effects. For example, there is the concern that romanLcisaLon is the problemaLc opposite of sLgmaLsaLon; the reversal of sLgma taken to an unhelpful extreme (Shrestha, 2018). SLgmaLsaLon and romanLcisaLon are both misinformed percepLons, and either can prevent people with mental health problems from being understood and treated fairly and sympatheLcally (Shrestha, 2018). There is concern that romanLcisaLon makes mental health problems appear trivial by dismissing their severity or their funcLonal impact, which can make those who do not romanLcise their mental health problems feel misunderstood and isolated (Gupta et al., 2021). Other evidence suggests that romanLcisaLon could lead to negaLve judgement from others, especially from adults judging adolescents' online behaviour (Niwa & Mandrusiak, 2012;Underhill & Foulkes, 2024;Zdanow & Wright, 2012a). Lastly, romanLcisaLon might discourage help-seeking, both in those who romanLcise their mental health problems (because they feel help is not needed), and in those who do not (because they are concerned they will not be taken seriously; Shrestha, 2018). However, to date, a comprehensive assessment of these possible consequences and implicaLons of romanLcisaLon is lacking in the literature.

In this paper, we present a narraLve review of research examining the romanLcisaLon of mental health problems among adolescents. This method was chosen due to the lack of consistent terminology used to describe romanLcisaLon, and inconsistencies in the methodologies used to explore the phenomenon. The review aimed to answer the following research quesLons:
(1) What is romanLcisaLon in the context of adolescent mental health problems?
(2) Why might adolescents romanLcise mental health problems?
(3) What are the implicaLons of the romanLcisaLon of mental health problems in adolescence?
(4) What are the intervenLons, if any, that can reduce romanLcisaLon of mental health problems in adolescence?

div.head: Method
div.p: Two searches were conducted in December 2023, on four databases: PubMed, APA PsycNet, JSTOR and Google Scholar. We first conducted a search of PubMed, APA PsycNet, JSTOR with the first three queries below in the Ltle and abstract, combined with the Boolean operator 'AND'. The second search included a fourth query regarding intervenLon, also added with 'AND', and searched for in the full text. This search was run to idenLfy papers relevant to the third and fourth research quesLons, about the implicaLons of romanLcisaLon; it was run separately to avoid inappropriately narrowing the search for papers addressing the first and second research quesLons. . Separately, an advanced Google Scholar search was conducted with all terms entered into the secLon labelled 'with at least one of the words', without Boolean operators or asterisks as the engine provides this funcLon automaLcally. These terms were searched for in the publicaLon's Ltles, which were screened along with the abstracts. All searches also included the terms (athlete) and (immun*), combined with the Boolean operator 'NOT'; this was done to prevent results that discussed idealisaLon in terms of athlete body image and resulLng mental health problems, or results discussing pro-inflammatory immune responses and depression. Both were added aier iniLal searches returned many papers focused on these topics that were irrelevant to our research quesLons. Aier all screening was completed for papers idenLfied in database searches (see detail below), we applied forwards and backwards referencing to the papers that met inclusion and exclusion criteria. For forwards referencing, the inclusion and exclusion criteria were applied to all forward-referenced arLcle Ltles and abstracts. PublicaLons were followed up for backwards referencing if they were cited as a relevant finding in the publicaLons already included; their Ltles and abstracts were then also screened using the inclusion and exclusion criteria. See Figure 1 for the complete search process.

PublicaLons were included in the review if they were wriMen in English and described or invesLgated any of the following: (a) representaLons of mental health problems that matched our understanding of romanLcisaLon (the unrealisLc belief, percepLon, or representaLon of a mental health problems to be more desirable or aMracLve than it really is); (b) posiLve amtudes towards mental health problems; (c) the encouragement of thoughts, feelings or behaviours associated with mental health problems (e.g. self-harm). PublicaLons were excluded if the adolescent populaLon was not discussed, either in relaLon to mental health problems, romanLcisaLon, or both. PublicaLons were also excluded if they described non-Western samples, due to potenLal differences in how other cultures may define adolescence (Sawyer et al., 2018) and in amtudes towards mental health that may affect how romanLcisaLon manifests, if it is present (Al-Shannaq & Aldalaykeh, 2023;Idubor, 2022).
There were no restricLons on publicaLon date. See Table 3 for full list of excluded publicaLons.

div.head: Results
div.p: A total of 61 arLcles were included for review (see Table 1). PublicaLon year ranged from 2005-2023. Methodologies included conceptual reviews and essays, systemaLc reviews, content analyses (qualitaLve and quanLtaLve), case reports and primary research, both cross-secLonal and longitudinal. The age range of parLcipants tested in primary research is 10 to 42 years. Most research used mixed gender samples, although some exclusively discussed female samples (Arseniev-Koehler et al., 2016b;Tanner, 2015;Thelandersson, 2018;Whitehead, 2010a) and some (such as those analysing social media content) were unable to gather demographic informaLon. Below, we describe the findings of the review as related to each research quesLon.

div.head: Research ques*on 1: What is roman*cisa*on in the context of adolescent mental health problems?
div.p: A variety of terminology was used in these arLcles to refer to the broader concept of romanLcisaLon. For example, authors described the glamorising, sensa1onalising and aesthe1cising of mental health problems (see Table 2 for full list of terminology and definiLons). Many papers referred to the promoLon or encouragement of behaviours associated with mental health problems, parLcularly referencing pro-eaLng disorder, pro-selfharm, and pro-suicide communiLes (Fitzsimmons-Crai et al., 2020;Keipi et al., 2017;Minkkinen et al., 2017). We considered this a form of romanLcisaLon, as it is involves encouraging others to view mental health problems in a more posiLve way (Zdanow & Wright, 2012a). The specific term varies depending on the way in which the mental health problem is seen as desirable (for example, because it is aestheLc, glamorous, useful, aMenLon-grabbing, or admirable), but the terms convey the same broad process of romanLcisaLon, i.e. the presentaLon of mental health problems as more posiLve that they really are.

div.head: How different mental health problems are roman6cised
div.p: Suicide. Much of the research invesLgaLng the romanLcisaLon of suicide described the glorificaLon of suicides or suicide-related content in news coverage (Gould et al., 2007a;Wang et al., 2023;Whitley & Berry, 2013). This involved sensaLonalised language choices in headlines (such as "shocking" or "graphic"), in descripLons of suicide aMempts using "success" and "failure" phrasing, and in phrases such as "freitod" in German newspapers specifically, a term that translates to "free death" and implies suicide is a means of liberaLon and empowerment (Arendt et al., 2018;Gould et al., 2007a;Wang et al., 2023). News reports also publicise celebrity suicides more than other suicides and may implicitly promote admiraLon of the person and their suicide by referencing their superior celebrity status (Stack, 2005).

FicLonal entertainment was also found to romanLcise suicide. Six publicaLons discussed the young adult (YA) novel and adapted Neblix series '13 Reasons Why', a story about the aiermath of a teenage girl's suicide (Carmichael & Whitley, 2018a;D'AgaL et al., 2021a;Inayat et al., 2019;Schipper, 2022;A. Shrestha, 2018;Wang et al., 2023). Commentary criLcises both the novel and TV series for seeming to glamorise several posiLve outcomes to suicide. In the story, the vicLm is martyrised and empowered in her death, as her 'suicide notes' (taped voice messages) gives her a voice that she did not have before; the story also involves several posiLve changes surrounding anL-bullying and mental health awareness in her school being made in her name (D'AgaL et al., 2021a). The story is also told through a romanLc lens, as the main character (a friend and romanLc interest) feels a stronger connecLon to the deceased girl because of her suicide notes (D'AgaL et al., 2021a).

The glorificaLon of suicide was also discussed in the development paper of the SLgma of Suicide Scale (SOSS; BaMerham et al., 2013), which to our knowledge is the only validated measure of any form of romanLcised amtudes towards mental health problems. This selfreport measure asks respondents to rate the extent to which they agree with a list of adjecLves used to describe someone who dies by suicide, and there are three subscales: SLgma, IsolaLon/Depression, and GlorificaLon/NormalisaLon. The final subscale best reflects romanLcisaLon, with adjecLves such as "brave", "powerful, and "fearless"; the scale's validaLon indicates that suicide is someLmes perceived by individuals and presented by the media as admirable, sensaLonal and as a means for achieving posiLve outcomes.

Self-harm. The romanLcisaLon of self-harm was typically invesLgated via content analyses and conceptual reviews. Methods oien used general search terms like 'self-harm' or 'self-injury'; however, most research findings focus on self-cumng, possibly because this is the most common form of adolescent self-harm (Hilton, 2017;Whitlock et al., 2006). Research in this area found that self-harm is romanLcised because it can be acLvely encouraged, with adolescents sharing techniques (Jacob et al., 2017a;Pater & MynaM, 2017a;Singaravelu et al., 2015a;Whitlock et al., 2006), promoLng the concealment of self-harm from others (Dyson et al., 2016a;Lewis & Seko, 2016;Whitlock et al., 2006), and defending it as a valid and liberaLng means of emoLon regulaLon (Tanner, 2015;Wester et al., 2017a).

Much of this research analysed pro-self-harm content online, either on websites and internet forums (Baker & Lewis, 2013;Franzén & GoMzén, 2011;Whitlock et al., 2006) or social media plaborms, parLcularly Tumblr and Instagram (Cavazos-Rehg et al., 2016a;Hajdú, 2022a;Seko & Lewis, 2016). The analysed content generally involved graphic photos of the individual's own cuts (Cavazos-Rehg et al., 2016a;Whitlock et al., 2006), although someLmes this self-harm was presented in a more aestheLcally-pleasing way with poeLc text, music and greyscale photos, which reduced the explicit shock factor of the photo (Pater & MynaM, 2017a;Tanner, 2015). Self-harm was also found to be a social norm in some adolescent groups and was promoted online as a 'friendship ritual' (Wester et al., 2017a;Whitlock et al., 2006).

PromoLon of self-harm in adolescents can therefore appear as a social behaviour, even becoming compeLLve at Lmes with adolescents aMempLng to have the 'most severe' selfharm (Baker & Lewis, 2013;Jacob et al., 2017a). Overall, self-harm is oien romanLcised online -adolescents use imagery and online communicaLon to present self-harm as a visuallypleasing, beneficial, valid, and socially acceptable and rewarding behaviour.

Ea*ng disorders. Conceptual reviews and content analyses also examined the romanLcisaLon of eaLng disorders, oien in 'pro-ED' content and communiLes online. As with self-harm content, pro-ED posts were found to involve graphic photos of extreme weight loss, paired with moLvaLng or poeLc capLons that present the disorder as a necessity for achieving posiLve outcomes, or as beauLful and profound (Custers, 2015;Fox et al., 2005;Tanner, 2015). Indeed, online pro-ED content (also referred to as 'pro-ana' and 'pro-mia', for anorexia and bulimia respecLvely) oien promotes eaLng disorders as an 'alternaLve lifestyle choice' (Arseniev-Koehler et al., 2016b;Chancellor, Lin, Goodman, et al., 2016;Day & Keys, 2008a;De Choudhury, 2015). These publicaLons described how those with pro-ED amtudes reject outside help and medical definiLons of eaLng disorders, as they do not see it as a disorder to be treated but rather as a way of life (Allison et al., 2013a;Mulveen & Hepworth, 2006;Warin, 2006). Individuals in these online communiLes equate beauty with low body weight and thinness, achieved through self-starvaLon, which becomes a measure of self-worth (Norris et al., 2006;Tanner, 2015;Whitehead, 2010a). In other words, research into pro-ED online communiLes show that eaLng disorders are romanLcised when they are seen by adolescents, and parLcularly girls and women, to be a method of increasing beauty and self-worth, and a method of reclaiming control over one's body; they may therefore be viewed as a posiLve means of achieving desired goals.

Similar to self-harm, there is a social element to the romanLcisaLon of eaLng disorders: studies found that individuals encourage each other's disordered eaLng by sharing techniques for restricLve dieLng or purging (Allison et al., 2013a;De Choudhury, 2015;Mulveen & Hepworth, 2006;Wilson et al., 2006a). Advice and encouragement for the concealment of eaLng disorders were also provided in pro-ED spaces (Borzekowski et al., 2010), and some posts were acLvely anL-recovery (Fox et al., 2005). Some pro-ED content used religious metaphors to encourage eaLng disorders by labelling dieLng and purging techniques as 'creeds' or 'commandments' (Borzekowski et al., 2010;Custers, 2015;Day & Keys, 2008a;Mulveen & Hepworth, 2006). Individuals received peer support in pro-ED communiLes (Chancellor, Lin, & Choudhury, 2016;Mento et al., 2021), and would someLmes compete with their peers on weight loss (Allison et al., 2013a;Mento et al., 2021;Mulveen & Hepworth, 2006). Online pro-ED content also personifies the disorder (referred to as 'ana' and 'mia'), either to present eaLng disorders as 'friends' (Day & Keys, 2008a), or as villains in scenariobased TikTok posts intending to be humorous or relatable (Schipper, 2022). In sum, the romanLcisaLon of both self-harm and eaLng disorders appear in the literature to be social behaviours, with individuals offering pracLcal encouragement of specific maladapLve behaviours, with some aestheLc elements.

Other mental health issues. Depression, bipolar disorder and anxiety occasionally appear as objects of romanLcisaLon in the literature. Some papers invesLgated romanLcised depression on Tumblr and Instagram where greyscale, aestheLcally-pleasing posts depicLng sadness or depression were accompanied by a poeLc message or quote (Hajdú, 2022b;A. Shrestha, 2018). Some users would tag their post with the terms 'depression' and 'anxiety' to increase the visibility of the post (Blair & Abdullah, 2018). These presentaLons portrayed the issues as aMenLon-grabbing, interesLng, and aestheLcally pleasing, implying that depression and anxiety have some desirable elements. Some posts make use of pop culture hashtags, images, quotes and music to present depression as visually appealing or humorous (Hilton, 2017;Schipper, 2022;Thelandersson, 2018). RomanLcised bipolar disorder appeared in a case report of two individuals who had self-diagnosed following celebrity accounts of posiLve experiences with the disorder (Chan & Sireling, 2010). The authors wrote that these celebriLes discuss feelings of heightened energy, creaLvity, and power, and describe the disorder as a valuable part of their idenLty, which may have influenced the desirability of this label in some paLents (Chan & Sireling, 2010;Shrestha, 2018). Together, this research highlights that many mental health problems are someLmes romanLcised, typically online: they are associated with posiLve outcomes like social reward (e.g. aMenLon, praise), stress relief (specifically for suicide and self-harm) or reaching ideal body types, and these messages are communicated among social groups.

div.head: Research ques*on 2: Why might adolescents roman*cise mental health problems?
Suscep6bility to social influence
div.p: In the reviewed literature, there were a number of explanaLons proposed for why adolescence might be a Lme of parLcular suscepLbility for the romanLcisaLon of mental health problems. The first is that adolescents are more influenced by their peers than other age groups (Cavazos-Rehg et al., 2016a;Foulkes et al., 2018;Wester et al., 2017a). Social contagion of eaLng disorders and self-harm among adolescents has been observed in hospitals, detenLon faciliLes, and schools (Allison et al., 2013a;MaMhews, 1968;Ross & MacKay, 1979;Warin, 2006;Wester et al., 2017a;Whitlock et al., 2006). Some papers referenced social learning and social cogniLve theory (Bandura, 2001;Bandura & Walters, 1977) to explain this phenomenon, describing how behaviours like self-harm are learned in adolescence through admired peers and the percepLon that the behaviour is normaLve, leading to social contagion of the behaviour (Custers, 2015;Walsh & Rosen, 1985;Wester et al., 2017a). The reviewed literature suggests that social contagion is enhanced when adolescents are exposed to explicit posiLve amtudes towards the behaviour, which can also occur online (Allison et al., 2013a;Lewis et al., 2012).
Other researchers highlighted the role of social belonging and its importance in adolescence.

Analyses of pro-ED and pro-self-harm content online found that adolescents express a sense of acceptance and belonging when parLcipaLng in these communiLes (Allison et al., 2013a;D. Baker & Fortune, 2008;Brown et al., 2020). Some research indicates that adolescents might search online for what they lack offline, as a sense of belonging in primary (offline) groups was associated with less exposure to pro-self-harm and pro-suicide websites (Minkkinen et al., 2017). Relatedly, other research indicates that adolescents seek out this content because it offers peer validaLon and understanding (Dyson et al., 2016a;Singaravelu et al., 2015a), group solidarity (Seko & Lewis, 2016), and establishment of a collecLve idenLty with shared opinions (Allison et al., 2013a;Day & Keys, 2008a;Thelandersson, 2018), all of which are important and highly moLvaLng aspects of adolescent social development (Tomova et al., 2021). This peer validaLon may lead adolescents to view mental health problems in a more posiLve light, i.e. to romanLcise them. One author wrote that the exchange of validaLon between adolescents on social media occurs in 'echo chambers' (A. Shrestha, 2018), where negaLve emoLon is reinforced through acceptance, causing adolescents to cling to these communiLes and, by proxy, to the mental health problem that the community is based around (Bine, 2013). Some adolescents are acLvely encouraged to conLnue with eaLng disorder behaviours (Borzekowski et al., 2010) and others are praised for their 'success' in extreme weight-loss (Allison et al., 2013a;Mulveen & Hepworth, 2006). Some may seek to gain pity and sympathy from peers online (Shrestha, 2018), or popularity through humour and aestheLc (Blair & Abdullah, 2018;Dunn, 2017a). Therefore, many adolescents evidently gain some form of peer validaLon for discussing their mental health problems, in the form of sympathy, praise and aMenLon; these outcomes may explain why adolescents romanLcise mental health problems.

div.head: Pop culture influences
div.p: Another reason why adolescents might romanLcise mental health problems is that they see these problems being discussed in relaLon to celebriLes, whom they view in a posiLve light.

In many reviewed arLcles, celebriLes are noted as a prominent influence on adolescent amtudes and behaviours towards mental health. Reports on celebrity suicides, parLcularly those that sensaLonalise the deaths, have been associated with adolescent suicide contagion (Niederkrotenthaler et al., 2012(Niederkrotenthaler et al., , 2020;;Stack, 2003). Pro-self-harm and pro-ED communiLes oien idolise celebriLes who have disclosed personal experiences with the same issue (Lewis & Baker, 2011), and individuals in these communiLes post images of celebriLes as moLvaLon, which can induce 'copycat' (contagion) behaviours (Borzekowski et al., 2010). Analysis of TwiMer posts found that celebrity fanbases someLmes defend and encourage self-harm in celebriLes' names; for example the hashtag 'Cut4Bieber' was used among JusLn Bieber fans who wanted to post pictures of their self-harm protest against his use of marijuana (Hilton, 2017). CelebriLes are already idealised by many young people and in the mass media (Thelandersson, 2018), so associaLons with mental health problems may cause the mental health problems to be idealised (and therefore romanLcised) by proxy.

Relatedly, adolescents are oien exposed to posiLve representaLons of mental health problems via ficLonal entertainment. Reviews of YA novels, films and television programmes that have adolescent target audiences idenLfied romanLcised representaLons of mental health problems. RepresentaLons like these are oien unrealisLc, as they do not reflect many people's lived experiences of mental health problems, which can involve significantly more misunderstanding and sLgma and significantly less support and aMenLon (Schipper, 2022;A. Shrestha, 2018). Young people, as the target audience for this entertainment, are more at risk of adopLng romanLcised beliefs from these representaLons. Norris and colleagues also note that relaLve to adults, adolescents may be less able to criLcally evaluate the content they are exposed to, perhaps due to their relaLve lack of life experience and less mature cogniLve development, which may cause them to view these representaLons as realisLc (Norris et al., 2006).

div.head: Iden6ty forma6on
div.p: Finally, the literature indicates that adolescents may romanLcise mental health problems because this contributes to their idenLty formaLon in a helpful or desirable way. Content analyses of romanLcisaLon online find it to be a form of idenLty exploraLon and expression (Arseniev-Koehler et al., 2016b;Bates, 2014;Nesi et al., 2021). Social media posLng is generally considered a rapidly changing, mulL-modal form of self-expression (Ito et al., 2010;Schipper, 2022;Wilson et al., 2006a). MulLple content analyses found that adolescents in pro-ED and pro-self-harm communiLes feel the anonymity and sense of community allows them to explore their sense of self through their disorder, whereas offline spaces and social groups do not (Arseniev-Koehler et al., 2016b;Bates, 2014;Blair & Abdullah, 2018;Hajdú, 2022b;Whitlock et al., 2006). ObservaLons of adolescents' posts on TikTok also find them to adopt mentally ill personas or 'roles' (Harness & Getzen, 2021). As discussed, idenLficaLon with one's mental health problem was common in content analyses of online mental health content, parLcularly self-labelling (Allison et al., 2013a;Pater & MynaM, 2017a;Shrestha, 2018;Thelandersson, 2018). Self-reports from adolescents engaging in pro-ED communiLes described the disorder as 'all-consuming' (Fox et al., 2005), implying that they had no choice but to idenLfy with the disorder. Others appear to idenLfy with a mental health problem because it offers a more helpful way of understanding themselves and their difficulLes, relaLve to any alternaLves, parLcularly for bipolar disorder or eaLng disorders (Chan & Sireling, 2010;Shrestha, 2018). Together, the research to date suggests that adolescents may romanLcise mental health problems because, through group idenLficaLon and expressions of their distress online, their mental health problems may have become an integral, helpful way of understanding their idenLty and accessing social support.

div.head: Research ques+on 3: What are the implica+ons of roman+cisa+on? Effect on mental health
div.p: There was a consensus across much of the reviewed literature that romanLcising mental health problems, regardless of what form this takes, might reinforce the individual's mental health problem, parLcularly if it is behaviour-based like self-harm and eaLng disorders (Arseniev-Koehler et al., 2016b;Hajdú, 2022b;Hilton, 2017;Shrestha, 2018;Whitlock et al., 2006). A longitudinal content analysis of pro-ED Instagram profiles found that the severity of the individual's mental health problem, indexed based on the post's content, increased over Lme alongside the extent to which the posts promoted (i.e. romanLcised) eaLng disorders, although the direcLon of the relaLonship is unclear; these two variables may have increased in parallel without necessarily having a causal relaLonship (Chancellor, Lin, Goodman, et al., 2016). However, qualitaLve data indicates that the sharing and learning of self-harm and eaLng disorder techniques in online communiLes can make the behaviours more severe (Whitlock et al., 2006;Wilson et al., 2006a), and the television series 13 Reasons Why was associated with increased teenage suicide rates (Bridge et al., 2020;Cooper et al., 2018), and increased use of adolescent crisis helplines (Thompson et al., 2019), suggesLng that romanLcisaLon may indeed reinforce or encourage mental health problems.

div.head: Effect on help-seeking
div.p: Many papers reviewed here suggested that romanLcisaLon may lead adolescents to have more negaLve amtudes towards help-seeking (Calear et al., 2024;Singaravelu et al., 2015a). Firstly, they may experience 'us and them' mentaliLes where they feel rejected and misunderstood by all except their online peer groups, thus making the individual reluctant to seek help from family members or mental health professionals in the offline world (Allison et al., 2013b;Dunn, 2017a). QualitaLve research with adolescents indicates that this mentality is reinforced by the increase in judgement, mockery and criLcism from outsiders because of online romanLcisaLon (Jacob et al., 2017b). Adolescents may adopt beliefs from their peers or the media about the incompetence of professionals and adults in providing support -13 Reasons Why, for example, presents the vicLm's parents, the school and mental health professionals as unable to understand and support the vicLm (D'AgaL et al., 2021b;Wang et al., 2023). Indeed, some may not wish to seek help at all if they believe they do not have a mental disorder, and many pro-ED communiLes define themselves as being uninterested in recovery (Sowles et al., 2018;Whitehead, 2010b). Many adolescents wish to conLnue romanLcising their mental health problems instead: analysis of some pro-ED Instagram profiles found frequent use of 'lexical variants' (hashtags with non-words that preserve the original meaning, such as "thyghapp" instead of "thigh gap") to bypass content moderaLon schemes (Chancellor, Pater, Clear, et al., 2016). These profiles had more engagement from other users with lexical variants than with regular hashtags, and these variants increased with complexity over Lme, possibly to ensure conLnued engagement (Chancellor, Pater, Clear, et al., 2016). Some research noted the potenLal beneficial effects of romanLcisaLon, parLcularly that it might be associated with more social support for adolescents with mental health problems.

Specifically, research has found that the sense of community felt by individuals in online spaces that romanLcise, parLcularly in pro-ED forums, can make the individual feel beMer supported than in professional therapeuLc semngs (Brotsky & Giles, 2007b;Yom-Tov et al., 2018). This was suggested to result from an increased level of understanding and acceptance coming from peers in these romanLcising communiLes. Similarly, in an interview study of young people who have self-harmed, parLcipants claimed that viewing romanLcised posts online, parLcularly on Tumblr, made them feel less alone, more understanding of the condiLon and more encouraged that they could endure (Hajdú, 2022c). Thus, one of the factors that leads adolescents to romanLcise mental health problems (the desire for social support), could also be seen as a beneficial effect of this pracLce -at least temporarily, for that individual at that moment in Lme. However, it is quesLonable whether this apparent benefit is truly useful for the young person in the long-term, given that romanLcisaLon can also reinforce behavioural symptoms of mental health problems and discourage help-seeking from anyone other than the communiLes that romanLcise the problem.

div.head: Direc6ons for Interven6on
div.p: In the final component of this review, we examined whether any literature proposed intervenLon guidelines or strategies to reduce romanLcisaLon and its associated harms. One proposed direcLon for reducing romanLcisaLon was to prevent it spreading online by censoring romanLcised posts, websites, forums, and hashtags. For example, a classificaLon mechanism was designed on Tumblr to remove 'deviant content' (mental health-related posts that violate community guidelines -mostly pro-ED content or extremely graphic or triggering posts; Chancellor et al., 2017;Chancellor, Pater, Clear, et al., 2016). The mechanism compared pro-ED content removed by Tumblr moderators (the classificaLon system already implemented on the site) with semanLcally similar posts, such as fitness and healthy dieLng content. It then analysed new posts based on these comparisons, and combined this with manual input from 'domain experts' who understood Tumblr guidelines and pro-ED communiLes. Censoring these communiLes is sLll a topic of debate, as it is acknowledged as a necessary protecLve measure for vulnerable people but risks inflicLng further sLgmaLsaLon on these communiLes (Arseniev-Koehler et al., 2016a), and removing their freedom of speech (Chancellor, Lin, Goodman, et al., 2016;Pater & MynaM, 2017b). In addiLon, such mechanisms can remove obviously graphic posts, but will likely be unable to remove more subtle forms of romanLcisaLon (e.g. aestheLcally-pleasing posts or messages offering admiraLon or approval).

In papers describing content analyses of social media or other online spaces, some general guidelines about reducing romanLcisaLon are suggested. These guidelines analyses advise clinicians, schools and parents to gather more informaLon on the internet acLvity of an adolescent, and to provide guidance to them on how to construcLvely use the internet, such as moderaLng social media usage (including knowing when to completely withdraw), paying less aMenLon to likes and following, and having open discussion with trusted adults about their internet use (Hajdú, 2022c;Singaravelu et al., 2015b;Wilson et al., 2006b). Lastly, there were some suggesLons that school-based intervenLons may be able to address the social basis for romanLcisaLon, as can individual intervenLons that assess peer networks (Allison et al., 2013b;Wester et al., 2017a). Beyond this, however, there were few proposals in the literature for how to reduce romanLcisaLon and its potenLal harms among adolescents, likely due to the lack of consistent research exploring what the phenomenon is and why it occurs.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: This narraLve review aimed to invesLgate romanLcisaLon of mental health problems in adolescence, which we define as the unrealisLc percepLon or presentaLon of mental health problems at this age as desirable or possessing any appealing qualiLes. The literature search idenLfied 61 papers discussing instances of mental health problems being held in a posiLve regard, and covered a range of methodology, including quanLtaLve and qualitaLve analyses of posts on social media, websites, forums, and news reports, self-report quesLonnaires, conceptual reviews and case studies. The review demonstrated that, when romanLcised, adolescent mental health problems are portrayed as beauLful, glamorous or interesLng, or as a useful means of achieving specific goals (parLcularly weight loss for eaLng disorders, and emoLon regulaLon for self-harm behaviours). RomanLcisaLon mostly occurred online, with frequent use of imagery, poetry, humour, and pop culture references. A number of reasons were proposed to explain why adolescents might romanLcise mental health problems, including the increasing normalisaLon of mental health problems in society, and the potenLal social benefits and idenLty benefits that romanLcisaLon might bring. Although a number of possible negaLve consequences of romanLcisaLon were proposed, parLcularly a decrease in help seeking, there has been limited research into how romanLcisaLon might be reduced.

There have recently been extensive aMempts to reduce the sLgma associated with mental health problems (Walsh & Foster, 2021). The current review indicates that it is crucial to understand whether, as sLgma has been reduced, there may have been a concomitant rise in romanLcisaLon. In other words, if the sLgma of mental health problems is reduced, these problems may not only become neutral but in some cases may become desirable. Some researchers propose that when awareness is raised and sLgma is reduced, mental health problems become normalised (Biddle et al., 2008;Prasad & Owens, 2001). Thus, perhaps de-sLgmaLsaLon aMempts to make mental health problems seem more normal and human have turned them into a social norm instead (essenLally, a behaviour we expect from one another). This would explain why more normalised mental illnesses like depression and anxiety are romanLcised more than sLgmaLsed disorders such as schizophrenia (Goulden et al., 2011;Shrestha, 2018). It is especially important to understand if adolescents are more suscepLble to this romanLcisaLon, since adolescents are more suscepLble to peer influence (Steinberg & Monahan, 2007), peer influence has been found to affect adolescent amtudes and sLgma surrounding mental health (Silke et al., 2017), and adolescence is both a period of mental health risk and significant idenLty development (Acheson & Papadima, 2023;Blos, 1967). In addiLon to this, romanLcised accounts of mental health problems appear in ficLonal entertainment aimed at adolescent audiences; it is therefore unsurprising if adolescents begin to idenLfy with problems portrayed romanLcally via popular ficLonal characters.

The current review highlighted the need for extensive further research. A key avenue for future research is to test the direcLon of the relaLonship between romanLcisaLon and other variables, such as normalisaLon, desLgmaLsaLon, personal idenLficaLon with mental health problems, and severity of mental health problems. This could be achieved with a combinaLon of experimental paradigms and longitudinal designs. The research reviewed here were typically based on cross-secLonal analyses of social media and website content that associate these factors with romanLcisaLon. NormalisaLon and idenLficaLon with the disorder have also been discussed as possible outcomes for romanLcisaLon instead of causes (Arseniev-Koehler et al., 2016a;Hajdú, 2022c). Future research could also assess associaLons between an individual adolescent's romanLcised amtudes towards mental health problems and that of their peers (using self-report measures such as the SOSS; BaMerham et al., 2013).

The effects of de-sLgmaLsaLon could be assessed with longitudinal invesLgaLon into adolescent online acLvity romanLcising mental health problems, following exposure to a mental health awareness campaign targeted at adolescents. If, as this review suggests, de-sLgmaLsaLon causes adolescents to view mental illnesses as a social norm that is desirable due to their wish to conform, we would expect romanLcised mental health-related acLvity to increase.

Future research should also examine whether romanLcisaLon or its impacts can be reduced. This is important, given that romanLcisaLon might trivialise or misrepresent mental health problems (Allison et al., 2013b;Dunn, 2017b;Underhill & Foulkes, In prep) or discourage help-seeking (Jacob et al., 2017b;Zdanow & Wright, 2012b). In the reviewed literature, recommendaLons to reduce romanLcisaLon and its potenLal harms oien involved increasing adults' understanding of adolescent social networks and social influence, or implemenLng one-to-one or group intervenLons with adolescents themselves, parLcularly focusing on the role of romanLcisaLon in idenLty formaLon (Allison et al., 2013b;Howard, 2008;Wester et al., 2017b). IdenLficaLon and disidenLficaLon with a mental health problem is a personal choice that clinicians cannot control; however, adolescents may benefit from addiLonal support in understanding how their mental health problems relate to their sense of self, as this could reduce general distress, reduce romanLcised beliefs that reinforce the problem, and prevent future distress should they choose to disidenLfy with their disorder.

div.head: Review limita*ons
div.p: There are a number of limitaLons to this narraLve review. The inconsistent terminology used in research invesLgaLng romanLcisaLon, and the lack of reviews that bring this research together, means that some research may not have been idenLfied with the search terms and therefore would not have been included for review. There are also limitaLons specific to content analyses of material on social media or the Internet, which was the methodology of several papers in this review. The search windows on Internet search engines, news databases or social media plaborms can be extremely brief, someLmes lasLng only one day (Arseniev-Koehler et al., 2016a;Carmichael & Whitley, 2018b;Moyer et al., 2008). Research findings can therefore become outdated and unrepresentaLve of current online environments very quickly, as posts, profiles, hashtags and even whole websites may be removed, deacLvated or moderated aier the data has been collected. Therefore, longitudinal content analyses may be more beneficial for observing and defining romanLcisaLon in such fast-paced online environments (Chancellor, Lin, & Choudhury, 2016;Chancellor, Pater, Clear, et al., 2016).

Online content included for analysis may also be specific to the country that the search was conducted in, as community guidelines and policies oien change with locaLon. Search engine and social media results oien change based on the individual's locaLon and previous online acLvity (Singaravelu et al., 2015b), yet none of the arLcles discuss the potenLal effects this may have had on their research. Several papers returned from the literature search invesLgated romanLcisaLon in non-Western adolescent samples; this small number of papers indicate that romanLcisaLon of mental health problems may also occur in non-Western cultures, but were excluded for the purposes of this review -further research is required to assess the extent of any cross-cultural similariLes or differences in romanLcisaLon.

A final limitaLon of analysing social media and forum posts is that demographic informaLon about individuals is oien unavailable or incomplete, which may undermine the conclusions drawn about adolescents in this review. Posters' age and gender were esLmated in some cases where the informaLon was not available (Cavazos-Rehg et al., 2016b;Dyson et al., 2016b;Lyons et al., 2006). If the age of most samples has been assumed or esLmated, the conclusions drawn about adolescent romanLcisaLon may not be accurate. Further research that combines self-reported demographic informaLon and longitudinal content analysis of the person's mental health-related online acLvity (for example, what material is posted, interacted with and searched for) could provide a more cohesive picture the individuals that romanLcise online.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: This narraLve review invesLgated the phenomenon of romanLcisaLon of mental health problems in adolescence: how it is defined, why adolescents might do it, what implicaLons this might have, and whether it can be reduced. Results demonstrated a range of phenomena that can be described as the percepLon or presentaLon of mental problems as desirable, indicaLng that romanLcisaLon is a suitable term for this collecLon of phenomena and can be used as a standardised definiLon for future research. The review indicates that romanLcisaLon of mental health problems is prevalent in social media, pop culture, news reports, and other internet spaces, parLcularly among adolescents. RomanLcisaLon can trivialise mental health problems, isolate young people with these difficulLes, and provoke judgement and mockery from others. On an individual level, adolescent idenLty formaLon appears to underlie many aspects of romanLcisaLon; on a populaLon level, efforts to de-sLgmaLsaLon and normalise mental health problems appear to contribute to romanLcisaLon. Further research using combinaLons of self-reported measures and analyses of online mental-health related acLvity can provide clearer direcLons to intervene at these levels to reduce romanLcisaLon and its associated harms.

figure.figDesc: The search terms were as follows: 1. (romanLci*) OR (glorif*) OR (aestheLci*) OR (ideali*) OR (glamori*) OR (pro) 2. (adolescen*) OR (teenage) OR (youth) 3. (mental illness) OR (mental health) OR (self-injury) OR (depress*) OR (anxiety) OR (selfharm) OR (disorder) 4. (treatment) OR (therapy) OR (intervenLon)

div.head: Acknowledgements
div.p: There was no specific funding for this project.

div.head: CRediT author contribu*ons statement
div.p: First author: ConceptualizaLon; data curaLon; formal analysis; invesLgaLon; methodology; project administraLon; wriLng -original drai, review & ediLng. Second author: conceptualizaLon; supervision; wriLng -review & ediLng.

div.head: Conflict of interest statement
div.p: The authors declare no conflicts of interest.
